__data__.text:
The key to mental longevity is not to keep your mind busy.

It's to make your life simpler than it is right now.

But simplicity can't be real until you start appreciating the small things.

It's about being humble without losing your ambition.

Because - as you grow older - life teaches humility. 

But not everyone captures these lessons.

My advice...👇

Stop the madness of living in complexity.

Shift your focus.

From chasing bigger things to cherishing little joys. 

At some point, not everything matters.

Don't wait to accept that.

Start today.

From chasing bigger things to cherishing little joys. 

At some point, not everything matters.

Don't wait to accept that.

Start today. 

🙏

10 steps to make an extraordinary impact in your new leadership role (before you even start): 👇

𝟏. 𝐑𝐞𝐬𝐞𝐚𝐫𝐜𝐡 𝐥𝐢𝐤𝐞 𝐚 𝐣𝐨𝐮𝐫𝐧𝐚𝐥𝐢𝐬𝐭:
❇ Dive deep into the company’s history, mission, financials, and strategic goals. Understand competitor and industry trends to hit the ground running.

𝟐.

Understand competitor and industry trends to hit the ground running.

𝟐. 𝐔𝐧𝐝𝐞𝐫𝐬𝐭𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐝𝐞𝐞𝐩𝐥𝐲 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐜𝐮𝐥𝐭𝐮𝐫𝐞:
❇ Explore employee testimonials, social media, and cultural statements. If possible, visit company locations to get a feel for the work environment.

𝟑.

If possible, visit company locations to get a feel for the work environment.

𝟑. 𝐒𝐭𝐚𝐫𝐭 𝐜𝐨𝐧𝐯𝐞𝐫𝐬𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧𝐬 𝐰𝐢𝐭𝐡 𝐤𝐞𝐲 𝐩𝐥𝐚𝐲𝐞𝐫𝐬:
❇ Arrange informal discussions with future colleagues, including peers, direct reports, and key stakeholders to understand their perspectives on company challenges and opportunities.

𝟒.

𝟒. 𝐅𝐫𝐚𝐦𝐞 𝐜𝐥𝐞𝐚𝐫𝐥𝐲 𝐲𝐨𝐮𝐫 𝐬𝐮𝐜𝐜𝐞𝐬𝐬:
❇ Set personal and professional goals for your first year, ensuring they align with the company's strategic objectives. Prioritize learning and integration.

𝟓.

Prioritize learning and integration.

𝟓. 𝐂𝐫𝐞𝐚𝐭𝐞 𝐲𝐨𝐮𝐫 𝐞𝐥𝐞𝐯𝐚𝐭𝐨𝐫 𝐩𝐢𝐭𝐜𝐡:
❇ Prepare a concise, engaging introduction about yourself and your vision to share on your first day or in initial communications.

𝟔.

𝟔. 𝐒𝐜𝐡𝐞𝐝𝐮𝐥𝐞 𝐤𝐞𝐲 𝐦𝐞𝐞𝐭𝐢𝐧𝐠𝐬:
❇ Before starting, arrange one-on-one meetings with direct reports and key team members for your first week.

𝟕.

𝟕. 𝐂𝐫𝐞𝐚𝐭𝐞 𝐲𝐨𝐮𝐫 𝐜𝐨𝐦𝐦𝐮𝐧𝐢𝐜𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧 𝐜𝐡𝐚𝐧𝐧𝐞𝐥𝐬:
❇ Set up regular check-ins and feedback mechanisms to keep communication lines open from day one. Commit privately (and then publicly) to a listening tour to gather deep insights about customers, processes, challenges, and team dynamics.

𝟖.

𝟖. 𝐂𝐫𝐞𝐚𝐭𝐞 𝐲𝐨𝐮𝐫 𝟗𝟎-𝐝𝐚𝐲 𝐩𝐥𝐚𝐧:
❇ Outline specific, measurable objectives to achieve in your first 90 days, providing clear targets for your early efforts.

𝟗. 𝐈𝐝𝐞𝐧𝐭𝐢𝐟𝐲 𝐞𝐚𝐫𝐥𝐲 𝐰𝐢𝐧𝐬:
❇ Select small, impactful projects that can be completed quickly to gain early credibility and show your effectiveness.

𝟏𝟎. 𝐒𝐡𝐨𝐰 𝐫𝐞𝐬𝐮𝐥𝐭𝐬:
❇ Focus on delivering your identified quick wins and communicate these successes to both your team and the broader organization.

In summary...

Your success in a new role begins way before you start.

It's a result of:

↳ Preparation
↳ Strategic thinking
↳ Commitment to making a difference

Follow these 10 steps and you'll make an immediate mark.

Agree? What would you add?

Agree? What would you add?

I led my first big team at 26. Here’s what I wish someone had told me before I started:

Background...

When my boss appointed me as manager at 26, I was excited and scared at the same time.

I was inexperienced and the youngest member of the team I would lead.

I had everything to lose. Great!

I was afraid to fail and of being judged and exposed as a fraud.

But I knew that I couldn't let my fear stop me. I had to try.

When I started, I had two options:

1) Be the "boss" and put the title first
2) Be humble, interested and vulnerable

I chose to be humble but my ego didn't like it first.

I felt like I should be able to figure things out on my own so the first couple of weeks I was in my own "manager bubble".

Things changed when:  

I realized that my people were the experts.
I was the student.

I told them that I would make mistakes. I asked for their patience and understanding.

Magic then happened. 

My team became so supportive and encouraging. 

They helped me to learn and to grow. They also gave me the confidence to make decisions and to lead the team.

Over time, I started to feel more comfortable in my role as team leader. 

I developed a strong bond with my team, and we worked together to achieve success. 

What happened next? 👇 

We broke a performance record that is still remembered by many in that company.

What happened next? 👇 

We broke a performance record that is still remembered by many in that company.

Here are my takeaways 20+ years:

↳ Age is not a barrier to success
↳ Always be humble and ask for help
↳ It's okay to be afraid. We're all humans
↳ Nobody knows everything. You included
↳ Without trust, it's impossible to win as a team
↳ Leadership is about empowering. Not being bossy
↳ The best leaders are the ones who are willing to learn

What’s your secret to successfully leading a team?

Not being bossy
↳ The best leaders are the ones who are willing to learn

What’s your secret to successfully leading a team?

Double standards kill the company culture. Here are 8 powerful actions to prevent that: ⤵

1. 𝗕𝗲 𝗰𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿 𝗶𝗻 𝘄𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗲𝘅𝗽𝗲𝗰𝘁:
↳ Communicate clear behavioral standards that apply equally to everyone in the organization, regardless of their position or status.

2. 𝗕𝗲 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗳𝗶𝗿𝘀𝘁:
↳ Model the behaviors you expect to see in others.

As a leader, your actions set a tone for the entire team, so ensure you act with integrity.

3. 𝗗𝗼𝗻'𝘁 𝗮𝗰𝗰𝗲𝗽𝘁 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝘂𝗻𝗮𝗰𝗰𝗲𝗽𝘁𝗮𝗯𝗹𝗲:
↳ Ensure that the consequences for not adhering to standards are the same for everyone. This reinforces the message that all employees are held to the same standards.

4.

This reinforces the message that all employees are held to the same standards.

4. 𝗪𝗮𝗹𝗸 𝗮𝗿𝗼𝘂𝗻𝗱 𝘆𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗼𝗳𝗳𝗶𝗰𝗲𝘀:
↳ Don't spend too much time behind closed doors, losing touch with what's happening in their organizations. You may unconsciously tolerate double standards.

5.

You may unconsciously tolerate double standards.

5. 𝗣𝗿𝗼𝗺𝗼𝘁𝗲 𝗿𝗲𝗮𝗹 𝗰𝗼𝗻𝘃𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻𝘀:
↳ Encourage team members to speak up about inconsistencies without fear of repercussions. Pretending that toxic behaviors don't exist is not a sign of leadership.

6.

Pretending that toxic behaviors don't exist is not a sign of leadership.

6. 𝗖𝗿𝗲𝗮𝘁𝗲 𝗮 𝗳𝗲𝗲𝗱𝗯𝗮𝗰𝗸-𝗱𝗿𝗶𝘃𝗲𝗻 𝗼𝗿𝗴𝗮𝗻𝗶𝘇𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻:
↳ Give regular and constructive feedback to everyone. This promotes personal and professional growth and demonstrates that all team members are valued equally.

7.

This promotes personal and professional growth and demonstrates that all team members are valued equally.

7. 𝗥𝗲𝗰𝗼𝗴𝗻𝗶𝘇𝗲 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗿𝗲𝘄𝗮𝗿𝗱 𝗳𝗮𝗶𝗿𝗹𝘆:
↳ Make sure that recognition and rewards are based on merit and consistent across the board. Avoid favoritism, which always creates the perception of double standards.

8.

Avoid favoritism, which always creates the perception of double standards.

8. 𝗘𝗻𝗰𝗼𝘂𝗿𝗮𝗴𝗲 𝗶𝗻𝗰𝗹𝘂𝘀𝗶𝘃𝗲 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗱𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗵𝗶𝗽:
↳ Coach leaders to be aware of unconscious biases and how they might contribute to double standards. Inclusive leadership promotes fairness and equity across the organization.

In summary: 👇 

A double standard is when you expect most people to meet a certain standard, but you give some other people a pass.

In summary: 👇 

A double standard is when you expect most people to meet a certain standard, but you give some other people a pass.

This is the most effective way to lose your best people.

Agree? What action resonates the most with you?

Admitting you're wrong is not a sign of weakness. It's a sign of extraordinary intelligence:

Because nobody is perfect, both you and I.

We both make tons of mistakes.

Here's the paradox:

The more you look vulnerable, the more people trust you.

But that's not enough.

Because talk is cheap.

Until you do what you say.

So... 👇 

Make actions speak louder than your words.

This is what people of integrity do.

Do you think leaders admit their mistakes as they should? 🤔

9 toxic habits that sabotage your performance (and how to fix them without feeling overwhelmed):

𝟏. 𝐅𝐞𝐚𝐫

Fear kills opportunities. It's our biggest limitation.

Tips:

↳ Face small fears daily to build courage.
↳ Visualize successful outcomes to boost confidence.
↳ Practice mindfulness to feel less worried.

𝟐. 𝐈𝐧𝐜𝐨𝐧𝐬𝐢𝐬𝐭𝐞𝐧𝐜𝐲

Inconsistency undermines progress and trust.

Tips:

↳ Create and stick to a daily routine.
↳ Set specific and achievable goals.
↳ Use habit-tracking apps to stay accountable.

𝟑.

↳ Set specific and achievable goals.
↳ Use habit-tracking apps to stay accountable.

𝟑. 𝐈𝐧𝐝𝐢𝐬𝐜𝐢𝐩𝐥𝐢𝐧𝐞

Indiscipline drives poor results and frustration.

Tips:

↳ Use time management tools to stay on track.
↳ Prioritize tasks by importance and urgency.
↳ Break tasks into smaller, manageable chunks.

𝟒. 𝐄𝐱𝐜𝐮𝐬𝐞𝐬

Taking excuses is just avoiding responsibility.

Tips:

↳ Hold yourself accountable for your actions.
↳ Stop blaming circumstances.
↳ Reflect and commit to change.

𝟓.

Tips:

↳ Hold yourself accountable for your actions.
↳ Stop blaming circumstances.
↳ Reflect and commit to change.

𝟓. 𝐏𝐫𝐨𝐜𝐫𝐚𝐬𝐭𝐢𝐧𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧

It increases stress and reduces productivity.

Tips:

↳ Create smaller steps and start with the easiest.
↳ Set deadlines for each step to keep momentum.
↳ Reward yourself for completing tasks.

𝟔. 𝐃𝐢𝐬𝐡𝐨𝐧𝐞𝐬𝐭𝐲

It damages relationships and your reputation.

Tips:

↳ Practice transparency in all interactions.

Tips:

↳ Practice transparency in all interactions.
↳ Admit mistakes and take responsibility.
↳ Build trust by consistently telling the truth.

𝟕. 𝐋𝐚𝐜𝐤 𝐨𝐟 𝐏𝐮𝐫𝐩𝐨𝐬𝐞

No direction destroys motivation and actions.

Tips:

↳ Create aspirational goals that align with your values.
↳ Reflect on what matters most to you and why.
↳ Create a vision board to keep your purpose in focus.

𝟖.

↳ Reflect on what matters most to you and why.
↳ Create a vision board to keep your purpose in focus.

𝟖. 𝐋𝐚𝐜𝐤 𝐨𝐟 𝐂𝐨𝐧𝐟𝐢𝐝𝐞𝐧𝐜𝐞

Poor confidence limits potential and willingness to try.

Tips:

↳ Focus on your strengths and celebrate small wins.
↳ Seek feedback and use it constructively.
↳ Practice positive self-talk and affirmations.

𝟗.

↳ Seek feedback and use it constructively.
↳ Practice positive self-talk and affirmations.

𝟗. 𝐀𝐥𝐰𝐚𝐲𝐬 𝐂𝐨𝐦𝐩𝐥𝐚𝐢𝐧𝐢𝐧𝐠

It kills hope, morale and productivity.

Tips:

↳ Practice gratitude by acknowledging the positives.
↳ Focus on solutions rather than problems.
↳ Limit time spent with negative influences.

Here's the good news... 👇 

You are in control of all the 9 habits.

Shift your mindset and create a new narrative that can empower you to make a difference.

You own the narrative.

How to change your organizational mindset to drive better results (without hiring an army of psychologists):

🌍 𝗙𝗿𝗼𝗺 𝗣𝗿𝗼𝗳𝗶𝘁 𝘁𝗼 𝗣𝘂𝗿𝗽𝗼𝘀𝗲:

↳ Why: Companies with a strong purpose outperform the market by 5% to 7% per year, grow faster and have higher profitability.

↳ How: Reconsider your mission as a business. Go beyond the financial goals. Create a new WHY that engages more deeply with today’s conscious consumers and employees.

Go beyond the financial goals. Create a new WHY that engages more deeply with today’s conscious consumers and employees.

 ⛓ 𝗙𝗿𝗼𝗺 𝗛𝗶𝗲𝗿𝗮𝗿𝗰𝗵𝗶𝗲𝘀 𝘁𝗼 𝗡𝗲𝘁𝘄𝗼𝗿𝗸𝘀:

↳ Why: Traditional hierarchic models are dying. Flat structures drive more agility and collaboration which always bring better results.

↳ How: Restructure teams to promote cross-functional collaboration, focus on breaking silos, creating a network-like workflow where people have more impactful conversations.

🤝 𝗙𝗿𝗼𝗺 𝗖𝗼𝗻𝘁𝗿𝗼𝗹𝗹𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝘁𝗼 𝗘𝗺𝗽𝗼𝘄𝗲𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗴:

↳ Why: Empowered employees are also more engaged, work harder, and become more loyal to the company.

↳ How: Delegate authority, give more authority and provide the resources needed for teams to make decisions at a local level. Let them be the heroes of your business game.

Let them be the heroes of your business game.

🔭 𝗙𝗿𝗼𝗺 𝗣𝗹𝗮𝗻𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝘁𝗼 𝗘𝘅𝗽𝗲𝗿𝗶𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻:

↳ Why: In a fast-paced world, the ability to adapt quickly is more valuable than rigid planning. It makes you more resilient.

↳ How: Encourage a culture of trial and error by implementing rapid changes, new ideas and feedback loops to iterate and improve swiftly. It's turning your company into a fast-learning organization.

It's turning your company into a fast-learning organization.

 💬 𝗙𝗿𝗼𝗺 𝗣𝗿𝗶𝘃𝗮𝗰𝘆 𝘁𝗼 𝗧𝗿𝗮𝗻𝘀𝗽𝗮𝗿𝗲𝗻𝗰𝘆:

↳ Why: Transparency builds trust and accountability in the organization. Both are crucial for success.

↳ How: Openly share information about company processes and decisions. Stop hiding information. Encourage open-door policies, transparent communication channels and be the leader who goes first.

In summary... 👇

These shifts are not just changes in operations.

They are fundamental transformations in thinking.

In summary... 👇

These shifts are not just changes in operations.

They are fundamental transformations in thinking. 

They prepare organizations to be ready for the future.

Which mindset seems to be more effective in improving results? Share it 👇

(Thanks Tanmay Vora for this wonderful representation)

Life doesn't define you.

How you react to what happens to you does.

That's what is in your control.

A quick piece of advice:

Start today to create your comeback story. 

🙏

Bad bosses taught me everything not to do as a leader. Here's what I learned so you don’t have to:

𝟏. 𝐂𝐥𝐚𝐫𝐢𝐭𝐲:
👉 Bad bosses are not good at clarifying their expectations and directions. 
Their ambiguity creates a strong sense of feeling lost and unproductive. 

𝟐. 𝐄𝐦𝐩𝐚𝐭𝐡𝐲:
👉 Their lack of empathy kills morale and prevents trust. 
Empathy is a superpower, creating an environment where people feel valued.

𝟑.

Empathy is a superpower, creating an environment where people feel valued.

𝟑. 𝐋𝐞𝐚𝐫𝐧𝐢𝐧𝐠:
👉 Blame games and finger-pointing are bad bosses' favorite habits. 
Mistakes should be accepted and discussed openly as learning opportunities.

𝟒. 𝐌𝐢𝐧𝐝𝐬𝐞𝐭:
👉 Bad bosses are models of stagnation. They resist change and cling to outdated practices. They are not interested in building a growth mindset.

𝟓.

They resist change and cling to outdated practices. They are not interested in building a growth mindset.

👉 Their leadership deficiencies sucked the motivation out of the room. Great bosses inspire and uplift their team, celebrating achievements, and encouraging them to reach their full potential.

You are 5x more productive when you reach the flow state (which has nothing to do with talent or experience). Here's how:

In a 10-year study conducted by McKinsey & Company, top executives reported being 5x more productive in flow. 

Flow is a mental state when you feel you are "in the zone":

↳ Feeling extremely focused
↳ Fully immersed in an activity
↳ You enjoy the process of the task at hand

My 7 simple suggestions to be "in the flow":

1. Set clear goals: 
▶ Set clear, aspirational but achievable goals for you and/or your team to provide direction and a sense of accomplishment.

2.

2. Balance the challenge-skills force: 
▶ Ensure your challenge level is balanced with your skills level (or slightly higher) to keep high engagement with the tasks without causing burnout.

3. Optimize the work environment: 
▶ Adjust lighting, noise levels, and workplace layout to promote concentration and comfort, which are critical for achieving flow.

4. Minimize interruptions: 
▶ Create a work environment that reduces all distractions. Build working practices like 'focus hours' where you and your team members work undisturbed.

5. Give autonomy: 
▶ Allow team members the freedom to approach tasks in ways that best suit their unique strengths and skills.

6. Give immediate feedback: 
▶ Provide real-time, constructive feedback to help your people adjust and feel valued.

7.

6. Give immediate feedback: 
▶ Provide real-time, constructive feedback to help your people adjust and feel valued.

7. Encourage skills mastery: 
▶ Be an avid learner. Provide opportunities for your team to acquire new skills and knowledge that not only match their job requirements but also keep them challenged and engaged.

Final observation... 👇 

Peak performers are not more talented.

They just know how to be more productive in less time.

Agree? What strategy makes you more productive?

How to make an impactful presentation (without spending weeks on dull PowerPoint slides): 👇

1. Passion always wins:
❇ Energize the audience with enthusiasm—use simple, clear language to draw them into your passion.

2. Be short and catchy:
❇ Summarize your product in a crisp, catchy sentence that could fit in a tweet, instantly clarifying the core message.

3. Power of three:
❇ Embrace the 'rule of three' for its simplicity and impact—grouping information in threes can be more memorable and engaging.

4. Stories make the audience stick:
❇ Introduce the 'villain'—the problem your solution solves—to highlight the 'hero', which is the solution you offer.

5.

5. People love heroes:
❇ Once the problem is established, showcase your solution as the 'hero' with compelling reasons why it's the solution.

6. Simple visual:
❇ Use slides that are visually appealing and easy to digest; minimize text to keep your audience focused on your message.

7. Lead with a personal touch:
❇ Share anecdotes about the solution's creation or role in your life, making your presentation more relatable and memorable.

8. Rehearse, rehearse, rehearse:
❇ Familiarize yourself with your material to boost your confidence and the smooth delivery of your presentation. Even if it's just a meeting.

9.

Even if it's just a meeting.

9. Engage, engage, engage:
❇ Avoid reading from notes as much as possible to demonstrate your deep engagement with the solution and confidence in your knowledge.

In summary...

Every conversation, meeting, and presentation is a unique opportunity to enroll people in what you offer.

But without:

↳ Preparation
↳ Attention to details
↳ Understanding of human psychology

It's just a waste of time.

How do you ensure your presentations leave a lasting impression? What resonates most with your style?

𝟏. 𝐔𝐧𝐝𝐞𝐫𝐬𝐭𝐚𝐧𝐝𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐬𝐨𝐮𝐫𝐜𝐞:

𝟓. 𝐀𝐜𝐜𝐞𝐩𝐭𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐢𝐦𝐩𝐞𝐫𝐟𝐞𝐜𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧 𝐢𝐧 𝐨𝐭𝐡𝐞𝐫𝐬:

𝟕. 𝐔𝐩𝐡𝐨𝐥𝐝𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐲𝐨𝐮𝐫 𝐬𝐞𝐥𝐟-𝐰𝐨𝐫𝐭𝐡:

Real culture doesn't show up in the good times. It shows up in the tough times.

It's all about how folks act when the going gets rough. 

That's the real test for companies.

My advice for leaders who are in this situation:

𝟏. 𝐀𝐜𝐤𝐧𝐨𝐰𝐥𝐞𝐝𝐠𝐞:

✅ Recognize and admit that there are toxic elements within the culture. 

This can be tough but is essential for authentic leadership and setting the stage for change.

𝟐.

This can be tough but is essential for authentic leadership and setting the stage for change.

𝟐. 𝐎𝐩𝐞𝐧 𝐂𝐨𝐦𝐦𝐮𝐧𝐢𝐜𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧:

✅ Facilitate open, honest discussions about the current culture. 

Create safe spaces for employees to express their concerns and experiences without fear of repercussions.

𝟑. 𝐋𝐞𝐚𝐝 𝐛𝐲 𝐄𝐱𝐚𝐦𝐩𝐥𝐞:

✅ Model the behavior you wish to see.

This means demonstrating respect, integrity, and transparency in every action and interaction within the organization.

When toxicity emerges, you have two choices:

You stick your head in the sand.

Or you take responsibility and do something about it.

What would you add?

9 toxic behaviors we need to stop normalizing (and how to do that):

𝟭. 𝟮𝟰/𝟳 𝗪𝗼𝗿𝗸:

🤔 Expecting employees to be always on is not only disrespectful. It will force people to disengage and eventually burn out. 

✍ Create and enforce clear work boundaries. Encourage employees to turn off work notifications after hours and respect their time off.

𝟮. 𝗠𝗶𝗰𝗿𝗼𝗺𝗮𝗻𝗮𝗴𝗲𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁:

🤔 Constant oversight makes employees feel undervalued and kills creativity.

Trust is key to empowerment and growth.

✍ Focus on setting clear expectations and outcomes, then allow employees to have the freedom to meet these goals in their own way.

𝟯. 𝗪𝗼𝗿𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗢𝘃𝗲𝗿𝘁𝗶𝗺𝗲:

🤔 Regularly expecting employees to work extra hours creates a culture where overwork is the norm and recognition is tied to time spent, not output.

✍ Acknowledge and reward efficiency and productivity, not just extra hours. Encourage employees to work smarter, not longer.

𝟰.

Encourage employees to work smarter, not longer.

𝟰. 𝗥𝗲𝘀𝗽𝗼𝗻𝗱𝗶𝗻𝗴:

🤔 Expecting immediate responses to communication disrupts focus and builds up stress.

✍ Establish reasonable response time expectations and use priority tags for urgent matters to reduce pressure.

𝟱. 𝗕𝗿𝗲𝗮𝗸𝘀:

🤔 Working without breaks decreases overall performance and can harm mental health.

✍ Promote regular breaks to recharge. Consider break reminders or structured downtime to ensure employees rest.

𝟲.

✍ Promote regular breaks to recharge. Consider break reminders or structured downtime to ensure employees rest.

𝟲. 𝗚𝗲𝗻𝗱𝗲𝗿 𝗦𝘁𝗲𝗿𝗲𝗼𝘁𝘆𝗽𝗲𝘀:

🤔 Assigning roles, tasks, or behaviors based on gender is discriminatory and limits the use of your people's talent.

✍ Develop bias training and encourage diverse teams where roles are based on skills and interests, not gender.

𝟳.

✍ Develop bias training and encourage diverse teams where roles are based on skills and interests, not gender.

𝟳. 𝗕𝗲𝗻𝗲𝗳𝗶𝘁𝘀:

🤔 Replacing meaningful benefits and support with less substantial perks makes employees feel undervalued.

✍ Offer benefits that genuinely improve employees' quality of life, like health insurance or flexible working arrangements, reflecting that you value their well-being.

𝟴. 𝗥𝗲𝘀𝘂𝗹𝘁𝘀:

🤔 Valuing only end results may lead to unethical behavior or cutting corners.

✍ Create a culture that values the process as well as the outcome. Recognize efforts and ethical approaches to achieving goals.

✍ Create a culture that values the process as well as the outcome. Recognize efforts and ethical approaches to achieving goals.

𝟵. 𝗕𝘂𝘀𝘆𝗻𝗲𝘀𝘀:

🤔 Equating constant activity with importance brings inefficiency and poor performance.

✍ Measure productivity in outcomes, not activity. Encourage strategic thinking and prioritize tasks to focus on what truly adds value.

Hard truth...

How you treat people always determines how they perform.

Treat them well. 
Make them feel valued.
Respect their intelligence.

So...

You have a powerful army ready to go the extra mile for you.

Patience is a killing venom for those who can't wait to get results. I know because I was one of them:

For a decade of my life, I couldn't accept being patient.

Any result was not enough for me. 

I always needed something more.

In hindsight, I believe I got trapped by the urgency of: 

↳ Working non-stop until ambitions are met
↳ Feeling always that something is missing
↳ Sacrificing most of my time (and family)
↳ Hating and fighting complacency
↳ Stop accepting the status quo

Everything seems great until you realize that the faster you try to change, the less you truly gain from it.

If you decide to play the extraordinary game, expect:

↳ Slow progress
↳ Doubts and fears
↳ A lot of time spent learning
↳ Longer journey than you thought
↳ One step forward and two backward

Patience is the calm acceptance that things can happen in a different order than you have in mind. 

– David G. Allen

How do you deal with ambition?

17 habits that separate confident from insecure people (+ my insights to help you navigate social interactions): 👇 

1. Mindset:
↳ Confident people are open to new ideas and different opinions. Insecure people are not very open and often think they know everything.

2. Validation:
↳ Confident people say nice things to others. Insecure people often look for others to make them feel good about themselves.

3. Learning:
↳ Confident people love to learn from others. Insecure people act as if they already know everything.

4. Responsibility:
↳ Confident people accept when they make a mistake and try to fix it. Insecure people often make excuses for their mistakes.

5. Principles:
↳ Confident people have strong beliefs and stick to them.

5. Principles:
↳ Confident people have strong beliefs and stick to them. Insecure people just do whatever makes them happy at the moment.

6. Mistakes:
↳ Confident people are okay with being wrong sometimes. Insecure people blame someone else when things go wrong.

7. Flaws:
↳ Confident people are okay with not being perfect. Insecure people try to cover up any weaknesses they have.

8. Thinking:
↳ Confident people usually think about the good things. Insecure people often think about bad things or what could go wrong.

9. Risks:
↳ Confident people are willing to take chances. Insecure people like to stay where they feel safe.

↳ Confident people think there's plenty for everyone. Insecure people worry there won't be enough and feel they have to take from others.

12. Giving:
↳ Confident people like to give and help others. Insecure people often think about what they can get from others.

17. Growth:
↳ Confident people keep trying to learn and get better. Insecure people often stick with what they know, even if it's not the best.

Susan Wojcicki has been Silicon Valley's most admired leader. Here's what I learned from observing her leadership:

1️⃣ Be Open to New Ideas
⇢ She believed that trying new things is important. At YouTube, she encouraged people to develop creative ideas and not be afraid to take risks.

2️⃣ Include Everyone
⇢ She always made sure that everyone felt included, no matter where they came from or who they were. She thought that having different kinds of people in a team makes the team stronger and better at solving problems.

3️⃣ Think About the Future
⇢ Susan didn’t just focus on what was happening at the moment; she always thought about what was best for YouTube in the long run.

This helped her make good decisions even when things got tough.

4️⃣ Stay Connected with Your Team
⇢ She made sure to talk with her team a lot and listen to what they had to say. This helped everyone work better together and feel valued.

5️⃣ Balance Work and Fun
⇢ Susan believed it’s important to work hard but also to make time for family and fun. She thought that if you’re happy in your life, you’ll do better at work too.

6️⃣ Make Decisions Based on Facts
⇢ When making decisions, Susan liked to look at the facts and information first. This way, she could make sure she was choosing the best option.

This way, she could make sure she was choosing the best option.

7️⃣ Be Strong and Flexible
⇢ When things didn’t go as planned, Susan stayed calm and changed her plans if needed. This helped her lead YouTube through tough times.

8️⃣ Think About the Users
⇢ Susan always thought about what the people using YouTube wanted and needed. She knew that if users were happy, YouTube would keep growing.

Final thought: 👇 

Susan Wojcicki was not just one of the biggest contributors to the tech community.

She was one of the kindest and thoughtful leaders.

Let's follow her example and make the world a better place.

RIP Susan 🙏 

What's your biggest learning from her leadership?

Most teams are allergic to conflict and this is hugely impacting performance. Here's how to solve it:

People - in these teams - are more interested in letting things go and pleasing their leader than confronting the truth. 

Let's shift the thinking 👇 

One of the key conditions for building a high-performing team is to create a culture of constructive conflict. 

It's about creating an environment where people:

⇢ Feel safe to challenge each other
⇢ Share their honest opinions
⇢ Debate the best way forward

Here are five ways to do that: 👇 

1️⃣ Build trust
⇢ People are more likely to engage in conflict if they trust each other to have their best interests at heart.

2️⃣ Set clear ground rules
⇢ Establish a set of norms for handling conflict, such as being respectful and listening to each other's perspectives.

3️⃣ Reward constructive conflict
⇢ When people engage in productive conflict, recognize and reward them. This will send the message that conflict is valued and encouraged.

4️⃣ Don't be afraid to fan the flames
⇢ If the team gets stuck, ask provocative questions or challenge assumptions. This can help to spark the conflict needed to move forward.

5️⃣ Give permission to disagree
⇢ Make it clear that it's okay to disagree with the boss or with other team members. This will help to create a more open and honest environment.

This will help to create a more open and honest environment.

In summary: 👇 

Conflict has a too negative connotation.

It can be painful but - provided it's not based on personal attacks - it can be equally powerful to get better results.

If you want to build a great team, don't shy away from conflict. 

Make it at the core of your leadership. 

What's your favourite way to build great teams?

Courage doesn't mean you're never scared. It means you face your fears when things are tough. Here's how to do it:

𝟏. 𝐅𝐚𝐜𝐞 𝐘𝐨𝐮𝐫 𝐅𝐞𝐚𝐫𝐬:

𝟐.

𝟐. 𝐓𝐡𝐢𝐧𝐤 𝐏𝐨𝐬𝐢𝐭𝐢𝐯𝐞:
⇥ Instead of thinking about what can go wrong, imagine what can go right. It all starts from picturing a positive outcome.

𝟑. 𝐀𝐬𝐤 𝐟𝐨𝐫 𝐇𝐞𝐥𝐩:

𝟒. 𝐋𝐞𝐚𝐫𝐧 𝐟𝐫𝐨𝐦 𝐌𝐢𝐬𝐭𝐚𝐤𝐞𝐬:
⇥ Everyone makes mistakes. Instead of feeling bad, think about what you learned and how you can do better next time.

𝟓. 𝐏𝐫𝐚𝐜𝐭𝐢𝐜𝐞 𝐌𝐚𝐤𝐞𝐬 𝐏𝐞𝐫𝐟𝐞𝐜𝐭:

🟢 You can keep trying and find new ways to succeed

Want to see real change in your company? Here's why creating a crisis can be your best possible answer...

This is what Stefano Aversa - the Global Vice Chairman of AlixPartners - shared with me on today's episode of The World Class Leaders Show.

But I know what you're thinking....

I don't need another crisis to deal with.

Here's another perspective:

When a real crisis happens - like a big problem or emergency - everyone works really hard to fix it: 

↳ People come together
↳ They think fast
↳ Make changes quickly

But what if there’s no big problem? How do we still make important changes?

Here's the idea of creating a crisis.

You can make small problems look bigger to get everyone’s attention.

Here's the idea of creating a crisis.

You can make small problems look bigger to get everyone’s attention. 

Here's why: 👇 

Find Hidden Problems
↳ Sometimes, problems are hiding and slowing down our work. By making these problems bigger, we can see them clearly and fix them.

Encourage Action
↳ When people see a big problem, they know they have to act fast. This can help get everyone moving in the right direction.

Build Teamwork
↳ Facing a big problem together can bring people closer. It makes teams stronger and more united.

How to do It: 👇 

Spot the Issues
↳ Look for small problems that are causing trouble.

Make It a Priority
↳ Show why fixing this problem is very important.

Make It a Priority
↳ Show why fixing this problem is very important.

Work Together
↳ Get everyone involved in finding solutions.

In summary...👇 

Creating a crisis helps your business stay strong and ready for anything. 

It’s not about making fake problems.

It's about finding and fixing real ones. 

This is how you mobilize people towards results.

What's your view?

He's one of the most successful CEOs. Yet, in 1996 his company was close to collapse. It's now valued at $2.2 trillion. Here's his secret:

Jensen Huang founded NVIDIA in 1993 but - three years later - he lost a major contract with Sega.

He needed to face layoffs and tried to keep the business alive.

The rest is history and well documented in this article.

On reflection, Huang realized what made Nvidia a global success.

His humility.

He experienced many failures. Both humiliating and embarrassing.

He was humble enough to admit his mistakes and ask for help by leaving his ego at the door.

He swallowed his pride because it was the right thing to do for his company.

He demonstrated that humility drives performance. Not just a healthy culture.

He swallowed his pride because it was the right thing to do for his company.

↳ They believe they are invincible

↳ They show how great they are at any time

Society doesn't need these leaders.

It needs 1 million leaders like Jensen.

Think you’re committed? Here’s how to really tell:

When you're committed to something, you're willing to:

↳ Put in the hard work
↳ Make sacrifices for the greater good
↳ Push through challenges to achieve your goals

Proof? You show:

↳ Dedication
↳ Perseverance
↳ Willingness to face difficulties head-on

It's about going beyond what's easy or comfortable.

Truth is? 
It's hard. It's really hard.

Here's what I notice in many organizations: 

Most people say they're committed... 

But they're just interested.

It's really hard.

Here's what I notice in many organizations: 

Most people say they're committed... 

But they're just interested.

If you're only interested in something you'll do only what is:

↳ Easy
↳ Convenient
↳ Comfortable

Your interest will create initial enthusiasm, but it's not enough to sustain effort when things get tough. 

You'll give up or lose focus at the first challenge because your dedication is shallow.

My final thought: 👇

Commitment is about depth and resilience.

While interest is about superficial engagement. 

But only commitment can drive your ambition.

How to truly value yourself and attract the right people (backed by science):

Research shows that individuals who truly value themselves attract and maintain healthy and positive relationships. 

Here’s why:

① 𝐌𝐢𝐫𝐫𝐨𝐫 𝐄𝐟𝐟𝐞𝐜𝐭
↳ According to the "mirror hypothesis," people tend to attract people who reflect their own self-view. 
↳ High self-esteem leads to attracting others who also value and respect them.

② 𝐁𝐨𝐮𝐧𝐝𝐚𝐫𝐢𝐞𝐬
↳ Psychological studies indicate that individuals with high self-esteem set clear boundaries and are less likely to tolerate disrespectful behavior.

↳ This creates and keeps healthier relationships.

③ 𝐏𝐨𝐬𝐢𝐭𝐢𝐯𝐞 𝐎𝐮𝐭𝐥𝐨𝐨𝐤
↳ Research shows that people with higher self-worth exhibit a more positive outlook on life.
↳ Which is very attractive to others.

④ 𝐑𝐞𝐝𝐮𝐜𝐞𝐝 𝐃𝐞𝐩𝐞𝐧𝐝𝐞𝐧𝐜𝐲
↳ A study suggests that those with high self-value are less emotionally dependent on others.
↳ Leading to more balanced and mutually satisfying relationships.

↳ Leading to more balanced and mutually satisfying relationships.

⑤ 𝐄𝐦𝐨𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧𝐚𝐥 𝐑𝐞𝐬𝐢𝐥𝐢𝐞𝐧𝐜𝐞
↳ High self-esteem is linked to better emotional resilience. 
↳ This means handling conflicts and challenges in relationships more effectively.

In summary...

Valuing yourself is not just good for the morale.

It creates a magnetic effect that attracts individuals who recognize and appreciate your worth. 

Final advice... 👇 

Start prioritizing self-value.

By setting clear boundaries and consistently practicing self-care.

Your value is not a byproduct of others' opinions.

It's a byproduct of your mindset and character.

7 techniques to combat decision fatigue as a CEO
(without reducing the quality of your decisions):

𝟏. 𝐏𝐫𝐢𝐨𝐫𝐢𝐭𝐢𝐳𝐞 𝐃𝐞𝐜𝐢𝐬𝐢𝐨𝐧𝐬
↳  Focus on the high-impact decisions
↳  Categorize decisions into
       - strategic
       - tactical
       - operational
↳  Use decision matrices or frameworks (Eisenhower)

𝟐.

𝐋𝐢𝐦𝐢𝐭 𝐂𝐡𝐨𝐢𝐜𝐞𝐬
↳ Simplify by reducing options to consider
↳  Establish criteria to eliminate less viable options
↳  While preserving mental energy 
↳ Create a decision checklist

𝟑.

𝐀𝐮𝐭𝐨𝐦𝐚𝐭𝐞 𝐑𝐨𝐮𝐭𝐢𝐧𝐞 𝐃𝐞𝐜𝐢𝐬𝐢𝐨𝐧𝐬
↳ Create systems that automate recurring decisions
↳ Use technology to handle routine tasks
↳  So you focus on more critical and strategic decisions

𝟒.

𝐂𝐫𝐞𝐚𝐭𝐞 𝐚 𝐃𝐞𝐜𝐢𝐬𝐢𝐨𝐧-𝐌𝐚𝐤𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐒𝐜𝐡𝐞𝐝𝐮𝐥𝐞
↳ Allocate specific time for making significant decisions 
↳ When you are most alert and productive
↳  Avoid doing it when you are tired or under pressure

𝟓.

𝐃𝐞𝐯𝐞𝐥𝐨𝐩 𝐚 𝐓𝐫𝐮𝐬𝐭𝐞𝐝 𝐓𝐞𝐚𝐦
↳  Build a team you can rely on for input and delegation
↳ Trust their expertise and judgment, and 
↳  Empower them to reduce your decision-making load

𝟔.

𝐒𝐞𝐭 𝐃𝐞𝐜𝐢𝐬𝐢𝐨𝐧-𝐌𝐚𝐤𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐁𝐨𝐮𝐧𝐝𝐚𝐫𝐢𝐞𝐬
↳  Set boundaries for when and where decisions are made
↳ Avoid making decisions outside of these parameters
↳ Such as during off-hours or without necessary information

𝟕.

𝐓𝐚𝐤𝐞 𝐂𝐚𝐫𝐞 𝐨𝐟 𝐘𝐨𝐮𝐫 𝐌𝐞𝐧𝐭𝐚𝐥 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐏𝐡𝐲𝐬𝐢𝐜𝐚𝐥 𝐇𝐞𝐚𝐥𝐭𝐡
↳ Prioritize your mental and physical well-being
↳ To sustain your decision-making capacity
↳ Regular exercise, sleep well and practice mindfulness

Final thought... 🙄 

Your decisions matter.

Worth taking them when you're at your sharpest.

Worth taking them when you're at your sharpest.

What technique seems to be more effective? What would you add?

Bad behaviors are like viruses.

They try to kill one cell at a time.

Until they spread without control.

Like viruses, bad behaviors destroy the host:

The organization.

Here is what happens if you don’t stop the virus:

↳ When managers engage in toxic behaviors, others may perceive these actions as acceptable and begin to emulate them.

↳ Over time, repeated bad behaviors can establish negative norms that become the standard within the organization, making it difficult for positive values to prevail.

↳ Employees who witness or experience bad behaviors become dissatisfied with their work environment, eventually leading to mental resignation and departure.

My advice… 👇 

Never let bad behaviours spread even if they look insignificant or isolated. 

Once you spot one, don’t walk past the trash. 

Leaders stop the virus and create a healthier environment.

Makes sense?

The kind of power that does not result from your title or status.

It's the real currency.

If you don't, they will take away what they wished for themselves.

Your confidence. 

Learning how to stop them is the way to preserve your power.

As a leader, you make many decisions.

So you trust your gut or experience.

Inevitably you’ll make mistakes.

But when you admit them in front of your people, they will trust you more. 

Guaranteed. 🙏

What makes any human similar to each other is we are inherently flawed due to a combination of:

Procrastination has nothing to do with laziness (even when it may appear that way from the outside):

Psychologists found that we procrastinate because we favor immediate gratification over distant rewards.

It makes sense based on how we are wired.

If you dig deeper, you realize that you procrastinate when you struggle to manage negative feelings about a task.

It is an emotion-regulation problem, not a time-management problem.

Often fueled by:

↳ Low self-esteem
↳ Self-doubt
↳ Anxiety
↳ Fear

It is a form of self-harm.

Here's how to shift your perspective: 👇

↳ Practice self-compassion
↳ Identify underlying feelings
↳ Break tasks into smaller steps
↳ Recognize it as emotional regulation
↳ Develop new emotional coping strategies

Remember...

That task you don't want to do can be the task that will make a difference.

Not just in your results.

But in the way how your integrity shows up. 🙏

Agree? What else would you add?

I spent years fighting the idea that life has no script.

When I was young, I believed in a simple path:  

↳ Learn at school
↳ Apply it at work
↳ Master your field
↳ Teach people to do the same
↳ Move to the top, earning credibility
↳ Inspire others with your learning and wisdom

We all wish it was that linear.

But reality hits hard:

↳ No one teaches you how to succeed
↳ Education falls short in real-life
↳ You feel often unprepared for challenges
↳ Dealing with people is complex
↳ There's no guarantee or easy path to the top
↳ You struggle to inspire yourself first

Lesson: 

The bigger your expectations, the easier is to get stuck in reality.

The gap can become your nightmare. 

Until you accept that success:

↳ It's not a result of shortcuts
↳ It's a long journey full of setbacks
↳ It's not a one-size-fits-all formula
↳ Differs from your initial expectations
↳ Ultimately, it's what brings happiness
↳ It's about finding harmony within yourself
↳ Is based on consistency and perseverance 

Accept it. 

You'll feel liberated.

What's your biggest and unexpected life lesson that didn't follow your original script?

Psychological safety doesn’t just happen.

It’s the result of leaders' choice.

Why it matters:

⇢ People need to feel safe to speak up
⇢ Innovation thrives in safe environments
⇢ Team morale improves with psychological safety
⇢ Mistakes are learning opportunities, not blame games

What leaders get wrong:

⇢ It’s not just about making people feel good
⇢ It’s not about being nice all the time
⇢ It’s not avoiding conflict

7 ways to create psychological safety: 🙏 

1.

𝙇𝙚𝙖𝙙 𝙗𝙮 𝙚𝙭𝙖𝙢𝙥𝙡𝙚:
↳ Show vulnerability
↳ Admit your own mistakes
↳ Be open to feedback

2. 𝙀𝙣𝙘𝙤𝙪𝙧𝙖𝙜𝙚 𝙤𝙥𝙚𝙣 𝙙𝙞𝙖𝙡𝙤𝙜𝙪𝙚:
↳ Ask for opinions regularly
↳ Create forums for discussion
↳ Listen actively without interrupting

3.

𝙉𝙤𝙧𝙢𝙖𝙡𝙞𝙯𝙚 𝙢𝙞𝙨𝙩𝙖𝙠𝙚𝙨:
↳Treat errors as learning opportunities
↳ Share lessons learned from mistakes
↳ Avoid blame and punishment

4. 𝙑𝙖𝙡𝙪𝙚 𝙚𝙫𝙚𝙧𝙮 𝙫𝙤𝙞𝙘𝙚:
↳ Acknowledge contributions from all levels
↳ Rotate meeting leadership
↳ Ensure everyone gets a chance to speak

5.

𝙋𝙧𝙤𝙫𝙞𝙙𝙚 𝙘𝙤𝙣𝙨𝙩𝙧𝙪𝙘𝙩𝙞𝙫𝙚 𝙛𝙚𝙚𝙙𝙗𝙖𝙘𝙠:
↳ Focus on behavior, not the person
↳ Be specific and actionable
↳ Offer support for improvement

6. 𝘽𝙪𝙞𝙡𝙙 𝙏𝙧𝙪𝙨𝙩:
↳ Be consistent in actions and words
↳ Keep confidential information private
↳ Show respect for differing opinions

7.

𝙋𝙧𝙤𝙢𝙤𝙩𝙚 𝙞𝙣𝙘𝙡𝙪𝙨𝙞𝙤𝙣:
↳ Recognize and address biases
↳ Celebrate diversity
↳ Make sure all voices are heard and valued

Final Advice...👇

Creating psychological safety requires commitment. 

It’s a continuous effort. 

Be vigilant and intentional. 

The payoff is a thriving, innovative, and engaged team.

Make psychological safety a priority. 

Your team will thank you.

7 trends I predict will shape your company's performance in the last six months of 2024: 

1. Purpose-Driven Leadership 🎯

Only 23% of what we think is positive. Here's how to get to 77%:

Only 23% of what we think is positive. Here's how to get to 77%:

Start focusing on the present moment.

Regrets (What we should have done)
Fears (What bad is going to happen)

🆘 You're never happy
🆘 You overthink vs enjoy
🆘 You get stressed and anxious 
🆘 You perform below your potential
🆘 You build a negativity bias about everything

✅ Spend time with supportive and optimistic people
✅ Join activities that bring joy and fulfillment

65% of executives say their decisions are more complex than they were two years ago. Here are 7 mental models to help you make better decisions:

𝟏. 𝐅𝐢𝐫𝐬𝐭 𝐏𝐫𝐢𝐧𝐜𝐢𝐩𝐥𝐞𝐬 𝐓𝐡𝐢𝐧𝐤𝐢𝐧𝐠

↳ Idea: Break down complex problems into their basic elements and reassemble them from the ground up.
↳ Why: You will understand the fundamental truths of a situation and find innovative solutions free from assumptions and biases.

↳ Why: You will understand the fundamental truths of a situation and find innovative solutions free from assumptions and biases.
↳ How: When faced with a challenge, ask yourself: “What do I know to be true?” and build your solution from these basics.

𝟐. 𝐈𝐧𝐯𝐞𝐫𝐬𝐢𝐨𝐧

↳ Idea: Instead of asking how to achieve your goal, consider how you could achieve the opposite.
↳ Why: You will identify potential pitfalls and obstacles by focusing on what could go wrong.
↳ How: For example, instead of asking “How can I succeed?” ask “How can I ensure failure?” Then, avoid those failure points.

𝟑.

𝟑. 𝐎𝐜𝐜𝐚𝐦’𝐬 𝐑𝐚𝐳𝐨𝐫

↳ Idea: When presented with competing hypotheses or solutions, choose the one with the fewest assumptions.
↳ Why: You will simplify complexity often leads to clearer and more effective decision-making.
↳ How: When making a choice, consider the simplest explanation or solution as a starting point.

𝟒.

↳ How: When making a choice, consider the simplest explanation or solution as a starting point.

𝟒. 𝐏𝐫𝐨𝐛𝐚𝐛𝐢𝐥𝐢𝐬𝐭𝐢𝐜 𝐓𝐡𝐢𝐧𝐤𝐢𝐧𝐠

↳ Idea: Evaluate decisions based on probabilities and expected outcomes rather than certainties.
↳ Why: You will develop a more realistic risk assessment and better preparation for various scenarios.
↳ How: Assign probabilities to different outcomes and weigh your decisions based on these likelihoods.

𝟓.

↳ How: Assign probabilities to different outcomes and weigh your decisions based on these likelihoods.

𝟓. 𝐒𝐞𝐜𝐨𝐧𝐝-𝐎𝐫𝐝𝐞𝐫 𝐓𝐡𝐢𝐧𝐤𝐢𝐧𝐠

↳ Idea: Consider the long-term consequences and the ripple effects of your decisions.
↳ Why: You will anticipate future challenges and opportunities that might arise from your initial decision.
↳ How: Ask yourself: “And then what?” after making a decision to foresee potential future impacts.

𝟔.

↳ How: Ask yourself: “And then what?” after making a decision to foresee potential future impacts.

𝟔. 𝐓𝐡𝐞 𝐄𝐢𝐬𝐞𝐧𝐡𝐨𝐰𝐞𝐫 𝐌𝐚𝐭𝐫𝐢𝐱

↳ Idea: Categorize tasks based on urgency and importance to prioritize effectively.
↳ Why: You will focus on what truly matters and avoid time spent on less important activities.
↳ How: Divide your tasks into four categories: urgent and important, important but not urgent, urgent but not important, and neither urgent nor important.

𝟕.

𝟕. 𝐌𝐞𝐧𝐭𝐚𝐥 𝐀𝐜𝐜𝐨𝐮𝐧𝐭𝐢𝐧𝐠

↳ Idea: Treat resources (like time, money, and energy) as non-fungible, assigning them to specific categories or projects.
↳ Why: You will manage resources more effectively and prevent waste.
↳ How: Allocate specific budgets for different projects or activities to ensure focused and efficient use of resources.

Remember...👇

Leaving a great legacy is not a function of noble intentions.

It's a function of the quality of the decisions you make.

Which mental model resonates with you the most?

It took me 3 days to prepare. 

I rehearsed 20 times.

Results? 

It was terrific. I felt proud of myself. 

Since then, I have been on stage multiple times, and I learned a few things about engaging with people👇 

𝟏. 𝐁𝐞 𝐞𝐱𝐭𝐫𝐞𝐦𝐞𝐥𝐲 𝐩𝐫𝐞𝐩𝐚𝐫𝐞𝐝

▶ You can improvise. You may even like it.

You may even like it. But don't
▶ 80% of preparation is about the flow, not the words
▶ Focus on 2-3 ideas max

𝟐. 𝐕𝐢𝐬𝐮𝐚𝐥𝐢𝐬𝐞 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐨𝐮𝐭𝐜𝐨𝐦𝐞

▶ I visualize a successful speech
▶ It boosts confidence
▶ Top athletes do the same. Because it works

𝟑. 𝐇𝐚𝐯𝐞 𝐟𝐮𝐧

▶ Be excited to go on stage.

I can't wait
▶ People don't get inspired by scared speakers
▶ Smile. Smile. Smile

𝟒. 𝐔𝐬𝐞 𝐦𝐞𝐭𝐚𝐩𝐡𝐨𝐫𝐬

▶ Metaphors connect reality with imagination
▶ Great speakers inspire people
▶ What you project is what people want to get

𝟓.

𝐅𝐢𝐧𝐢𝐬𝐡 𝐬𝐭𝐫𝐨𝐧𝐠

▶ People don't expect an action list
▶ People expect to see things differently
▶ Your job is to expand their thinking

Final advice... ✍️

You don't need to go on stage to engage people in your idea.

You engage - or don't - people every day.

When you meet or have a call with them.

But how you prepare for that conversation is what will eventually matter.

When running meetings, many leaders fall into a big trap.

They start by pointing out what's missing.
Thinking it will speed up progress. 

I had a client who used to do this every time. 

His team left meetings feeling stressed and thinking, "It's never enough here".

The result? More stress, less progress.

His team left meetings feeling stressed and thinking, "It's never enough here".

The result? More stress, less progress.

Here’s what I offered to my client:

✳️ Celebrate Wins: 
→ We started meetings by celebrating wins, big or small
→ This created a positive vibe right from the start

✳️ Highlight Progress: 
→ We focused on the progress made toward goals 
→ This helped the team focus on achievements 
→ It boosted their confidence

✳️ Recognize Efforts: 
→ Highlighting accomplishments energized the team
→ It wasn’t just a mood booster
→ It fired them up to improve

✳️ Set a Positive Tone: 
→ Starting on a high note makes a big difference
→ It makes the whole meeting more constructive
→ And less stressful

Final thought:

Stop stressing your team with negativity.

Start with positivity and build momentum. 🙏 

Positive starts don’t just lift spirits; they drive progress.

PS: How do you start your meetings? Try beginning with a win. It makes a big difference.

Here’s my advice for facing adversity in business: 

1. Double down on what your organization does best
2. Then inspire teams toward a future only they can see yet

This is what Alan Mulally did when he took Ford Motor Company's helm in 2006 after the company had posted a $12.7 billion annual loss and declining sales in a troubled US auto industry. 

Ford was widely predicted to go bankrupt along with General Motors and Chrysler during the economic recession.

However... 🤔  

By 2011, Ford reported profits of $20.2 billion and passed GM and Toyota as the #2 US carmaker. 

Mulally's story is one of history's greatest corporate comebacks.

Mulally's story is one of history's greatest corporate comebacks.

Here is how he did it (and what we can learn from him): 👇 

𝟏) 𝐀𝐝𝐝𝐫𝐞𝐬𝐬 𝐩𝐫𝐨𝐛𝐥𝐞𝐦𝐬 𝐡𝐞𝐚𝐝-𝐨𝐧

Mulally tackled Ford's declining market position and debt urgently by mortgaging assets before it was too late, despite how controversial borrowing $23.5 billion seemed at the time.

𝟐) 𝐅𝐨𝐜𝐮𝐬 𝐨𝐧 𝐲𝐨𝐮𝐫 𝐬𝐭𝐫𝐞𝐧𝐠𝐭𝐡𝐬

Mulally recognized that quality fuel-efficient models were Ford's strength. He directed research and operations exclusively toward smaller cars and energy-efficient engines that consumers demanded more post-recession.

He directed research and operations exclusively toward smaller cars and energy-efficient engines that consumers demanded more post-recession. 

𝟑) 𝐂𝐨𝐦𝐦𝐮𝐧𝐢𝐜𝐚𝐭𝐞 𝐰𝐢𝐭𝐡 𝐜𝐥𝐚𝐫𝐢𝐭𝐲 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐭𝐫𝐚𝐧𝐬𝐩𝐚𝐫𝐞𝐧𝐜𝐲

Mulally instituted weekly meetings with executives to identify problems quickly and shifted culture to reward openness.

He created a transparent culture that empowered better decision-making at all levels - creating alignment and accountability.

𝟒) 𝐋𝐞𝐚𝐝 𝐰𝐢𝐭𝐡 𝐡𝐞𝐚𝐫𝐭 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐨𝐩𝐭𝐢𝐦𝐢𝐬𝐦

Mulally gave Ford teams an inspirational vision during dark days - calling employees "one Ford" and saying "Together we can pull this off". His optimism and appeal to shared identity lifted spirits until operational changes took hold.

His optimism and appeal to shared identity lifted spirits until operational changes took hold.

In summary...👇 

↳ Deep dive on what's not working
↳ Don't get stuck in over-analysis 
↳ Act fast
↳ Focus on what you do well
↳ Encourage transparent conversations
↳ Inspire hope and belief in possibilities

This is a great formula for a comeback story. 👊

20% of employees in the UK are quiet quitters. Here’s how to win them back:

Quiet quitters have already:

↳ Mentally resigned
↳ Decided to leave their company

They are not just less satisfied than other employees. 

They are building a huge cost for organizations. According to McKinsey & Company, the cost of such disengagement adds up to around 4% of the wage bill for an average company.

In my experience working for many organizations, I believe these 7 strategies can help you to get them mentally back: 👇 

1.

In my experience working for many organizations, I believe these 7 strategies can help you to get them mentally back: 👇

↳ Offer clear career paths and opportunities for people to progress in the organization. You invested in them over the years. What's the point of keeping them where they are forever?

2.

You invested in them over the years. What's the point of keeping them where they are forever?

↳ Influence the right culture that is supportive, inclusive, and rewards performance. Address any signs of a toxic environment as soon as they happen.   Don't let a toxic culture eat your company.

3.

Address any signs of a toxic environment as soon as they happen.   Don't let a toxic culture eat your company.

3. 𝙎𝙚𝙩 𝙘𝙡𝙚𝙖𝙧 𝙀𝙓𝙋𝙀𝘾𝙏𝘼𝙏𝙄𝙊𝙉𝙎

↳ Define and communicate clear roles and responsibilities. People hate unnecessary ambiguity. Provide specific, achievable goals and regular feedback to make sure employees understand what is expected of them.

4.

People hate unnecessary ambiguity. Provide specific, achievable goals and regular feedback to make sure employees understand what is expected of them.

4. 𝙎𝙝𝙤𝙬 𝘼𝙋𝙋𝙍𝙀𝘾𝙄𝘼𝙏𝙄𝙊𝙉

↳ Recognize and reward employees for their results and contributions. Use both formal rewards (bonuses, promotions) and informal acknowledgments (thank-you notes, public praise). They need both. Equally powerful.

They need both. Equally powerful.

↳ Prevent burnout and unnecessary stress by promoting a healthy way of working. Offer flexible working hours, remote work options, and encourage employees to take breaks, rest, recover and have fun!

7.

Offer flexible working hours, remote work options, and encourage employees to take breaks, rest, recover and have fun!

7. 𝙇𝙚𝙩 𝙩𝙝𝙚𝙢 𝙢𝙖𝙠𝙚 𝘿𝙀𝘾𝙄𝙎𝙄𝙊𝙉𝙎

This book has changed many people’s lives. Here’s how you can turn Covey’s principles into practical steps: 👊 

𝟏. 𝐁𝐞 𝐏𝐫𝐨𝐚𝐜𝐭𝐢𝐯𝐞

🔶 Idea: 
Focus on what you can control and take initiative.

🔷 Practical application:
↳ Create a "Circle of Influence" and "Circle of Concern."
↳ Spend 10 minutes each morning identifying actions within your control that align with your goals and make a positive impact.

𝟐.

↳ Spend 10 minutes each morning identifying actions within your control that align with your goals and make a positive impact.

𝟐. 𝐁𝐞𝐠𝐢𝐧 𝐰𝐢𝐭𝐡 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐄𝐧𝐝 𝐢𝐧 𝐌𝐢𝐧𝐝

🔶 Idea: 
Envision your future using both logic and imagination.

🔷 Practical application:
↳ Write a detailed personal mission statement.
↳ Reflect on your long-term goals and values.
↳ Outline steps you can take each week to move closer to these objectives.

𝟑.

↳ Outline steps you can take each week to move closer to these objectives.

𝟑. 𝐏𝐮𝐭 𝐅𝐢𝐫𝐬𝐭 𝐓𝐡𝐢𝐧𝐠𝐬 𝐅𝐢𝐫𝐬𝐭

🔶 Idea: 
Prioritize tasks based on importance and urgency.

🔷 Practical application:
↳ Use a quadrant matrix to categorize tasks into four groups: important and urgent, important but not urgent, urgent but not important, and neither urgent nor important.
↳ Schedule your week to focus primarily on important but not urgent tasks to achieve long-term goals.

𝟒.

↳ Schedule your week to focus primarily on important but not urgent tasks to achieve long-term goals.

𝟒. 𝐓𝐡𝐢𝐧𝐤 𝐖𝐢𝐧-𝐖𝐢𝐧

🔶 Idea: 
Seek mutually beneficial solutions.

🔷 Practical application:
↳ When faced with a negotiation or decision, list the needs and wants of all parties involved.
↳ Develop at least three alternative solutions that provide mutual benefits, and discuss these openly to reach a win-win outcome.

𝟓.

↳ Develop at least three alternative solutions that provide mutual benefits, and discuss these openly to reach a win-win outcome.

𝟓. 𝐒𝐞𝐞𝐤 𝐅𝐢𝐫𝐬𝐭 𝐭𝐨 𝐔𝐧𝐝𝐞𝐫𝐬𝐭𝐚𝐧𝐝, 𝐓𝐡𝐞𝐧 𝐭𝐨 𝐁𝐞 𝐔𝐧𝐝𝐞𝐫𝐬𝐭𝐨𝐨𝐝

🔶 Idea: 
Listen actively before expressing your own viewpoint.

🔷 Practical application:
↳ Practice active listening by using reflective statements.
↳ When someone speaks, summarize their points to confirm understanding before sharing your perspective.

𝟔. 𝐒𝐲𝐧𝐞𝐫𝐠𝐢𝐳𝐞

🔶 Idea: 
Combine strengths through teamwork for better results.

🔷 Practical application:
↳ Organize regular team brainstorming sessions where all members are encouraged to contribute ideas.
↳ Utilize diverse skills and perspectives to solve problems more creatively and effectively.

𝟕.

↳ Utilize diverse skills and perspectives to solve problems more creatively and effectively.

𝟕. 𝐒𝐡𝐚𝐫𝐩𝐞𝐧 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐒𝐚𝐰

🔶 Idea: 
Continuously improve your physical, mental, and emotional health.

🔷 Practical application:
↳ Schedule weekly activities that address physical (exercise), mental (learning), social/emotional (connecting with others), and spiritual (reflection or meditation) health.

Adopting these 7 habits will make your leadership better.

I led my first large team at 26. Here’s what I learned to lift your team to the next level: 👇 

When my boss appointed me as manager at 26, I was excited and scared at the same time.

I was young and inexperienced, and also the youngest member of the team I would lead.

I had everything to lose. Bingo. 💥 

I was afraid to fail and of being judged and exposed as a fraud.

But I knew that I couldn't let my fear stop me. I had to try.

When I started, I had two options:

1) Be the "boss" and put the title at work
2) Be humble, genuinely interested and vulnerable

I chose 2) but my ego didn't like it first.

I felt like I should be able to figure things out on my own so the first couple of weeks I was in my own "manager bubble".

Things changed when: 🤔 

I realized that my people were the experts.
I was the student.

I told them that I would make mistakes. I asked for their patience and understanding.

Magic then happened. 

My team became so supportive and encouraging. They helped me to learn and to grow. They also gave me the confidence to make decisions and to lead the team.

Over time, I started to feel more comfortable in my role as team leader. I developed a strong bond with my team, and we worked together to achieve success. 

What happened next? 👇 

We broke a performance record that is still remembered by many in that company.

What happened next? 👇 

We broke a performance record that is still remembered by many in that company.

Here are my takeaways after 23 years:

↳ Age is not a barrier to success
↳ Always be humble and ask for help
↳ It's okay to be afraid. We're all humans
↳ Nobody knows everything. You included
↳ Without trust, it's impossible to win as a team
↳ Leadership is about empowering. Not being bossy
↳ The best leaders are the ones who are willing to learn

What else did you learn from leading a successful team?

Not being bossy
↳ The best leaders are the ones who are willing to learn

What else did you learn from leading a successful team?

5 proven models to boost your team's performance (with my simple explanations and clear benefits) 👇 

𝟏. 𝐓𝐮𝐜𝐤𝐦𝐚𝐧 𝐌𝐨𝐝𝐞𝐥

🔬  𝙀𝙭𝙥𝙡𝙖𝙣𝙖𝙩𝙞𝙤𝙣: Teams progress through four stages: Forming (getting to know each other), Storming (conflict arises), Norming (settling into roles), and Performing (working effectively towards goals).

✳ 𝙑𝙖𝙡𝙪𝙚: Understanding these stages helps leaders manage team dynamics and conflict, leading to higher performance.

𝟐. 𝐊𝐚𝐭𝐳𝐞𝐧𝐛𝐚𝐜𝐡 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐒𝐦𝐢𝐭𝐡 𝐌𝐨𝐝𝐞𝐥

🔬  𝙀𝙭𝙥𝙡𝙖𝙣𝙖𝙩𝙞𝙤𝙣: Focuses on the importance of skills, mutual and individual accountability, and commitment to a common purpose.

✳ 𝙑𝙖𝙡𝙪𝙚: This model helps in building a strong, cohesive team that is highly committed and accountable, improving overall performance.

𝟑. 𝐇𝐢𝐠𝐡-𝐏𝐞𝐫𝐟𝐨𝐫𝐦𝐚𝐧𝐜𝐞 𝐓𝐞𝐚𝐦 𝐌𝐨𝐝𝐞𝐥

🔬  𝙀𝙭𝙥𝙡𝙖𝙣𝙖𝙩𝙞𝙤𝙣: Combines performance development and change management to enhance team capabilities.

✳ 𝙑𝙖𝙡𝙪𝙚: This integrated approach ensures teams are adaptable and can handle change effectively, leading to sustained high performance.

𝟒. 𝐇𝐚𝐜𝐤𝐦𝐚𝐧 𝐌𝐨𝐝𝐞𝐥

🔬 𝙀𝙭𝙥𝙡𝙖𝙣𝙖𝙩𝙞𝙤𝙣: Emphasizes core dimensions like task variety and feedback, psychological states like meaningfulness and responsibility, and outcomes such as motivation and job satisfaction.

✳ 𝙑𝙖𝙡𝙪𝙚: Focuses on designing tasks that motivate employees, leading to higher job satisfaction, better performance, and reduced turnover.

𝟓. 𝐆𝐑𝐏𝐈 𝐌𝐨𝐝𝐞𝐥

🔬 𝙀𝙭𝙥𝙡𝙖𝙣𝙖𝙩𝙞𝙤𝙣: Stands for Goals, Roles, Processes, and Interpersonal Relationships. It ensures clarity in what needs to be done, who does it, how it’s done, and how team members interact.

Humility.

True leadership is about creating an environment where everyone feels comfortable speaking up.

Not overshadowing people's voices.

So...

If your people don't talk, look at how much space you created for hearing their voices.

People don't speak up by default.

They speak up by design.

Agree? What else makes people stay silent?

I am horrified to hear another story of a professional who died from overwork. This is his story and what it means for us:

John - a promising young banker on Wall Street - recently died of a heart attack brought on by extreme stress and exhaustion.

He was known for his dedication and long hours. 

He routinely worked 100-hour weeks.

Like many, he was striving to climb the corporate ladder. 

His peers are now demanding change.

Here's my view on the current situation... 🤔 

1. Work can't be what it is right now:

↳ Long hours lead to severe stress and health issues
↳ Employees need to rest and recharge to be productive
↳ Life is more important than work

2.

Company culture needs to prioritize health:

↳ A toxic work culture that glorifies overwork is harmful
↳ Companies should promote a healthy workplace
↳ Mental health support should be accessible to everyone

3.

Setting boundaries:

↳ Clear boundaries between work and personal life
↳ Employees should be able to say no to unreasonable demands
↳ Regular breaks and time off prevent burnout

Here are my recommendations...

↳ Give access to counselling and support 
↳ Organize workshops on stress management
↳ Tasks to be distributed evenly and realistically
↳ More remote work to reduce commuting stress
↳ More check-ins with employees about workload
↳ Create a culture where seeking help is normalized
↳ Promote a results-oriented culture vs clocking hours
↳ Allow employees to have control over their schedules

What do you think? What needs to be true to prevent other professionals from dying at work because of excessive stress and workload?

How to change your organizational mindset to drive better results: 
(without hiring an army of psychologists) 👇 

🌍 From Profit to Purpose:

↳ Why: Companies with a strong purpose outperform the market by 5% to 7% per year, grow faster and have higher profitability.

↳ How: Reconsider your mission as a business. Go beyond the financial goals. Create a new WHY that engages more deeply with today’s conscious consumers and employees.

 ⛓ From Hierarchies to Networks:

↳ Why: Traditional hierarchic models are dying. Flat structures drive more agility and collaboration which always bring better results.

↳ How: Restructure teams to promote cross-functional collaboration, focus on breaking silos, creating a network-like workflow where people have more impactful conversations.

🤝 From Controlling to Empowering:

↳ Why: Empowered employees are also more engaged, work harder, and become more loyal to the company.

↳ How: Delegate authority, give more authority and provide the resources needed for teams to make decisions at a local level. Let them be the heroes of your business game.

🔭 From Planning to Experimentation:

↳ Why: In a fast-paced world, the ability to adapt quickly is more valuable than rigid planning. It makes you more resilient.

↳ How: Encourage a culture of trial and error by implementing rapid changes, new ideas and feedback loops to iterate and improve swiftly. It's turning your company into a fast-learning organization.

 💬 From Privacy to Transparency:

↳ Why: Transparency builds trust and accountability in the organization.

💬 From Privacy to Transparency:

↳ Why: Transparency builds trust and accountability in the organization. Both are crucial for success.

↳ How: Openly share information about company processes and decisions. Stop hiding information. Encourage open-door policies, transparent communication channels and be the leader who goes first.

In summary... ✅ 

These shifts are not just changes in operations.

They are fundamental transformations in thinking. 

They prepare organizations to be ready for the future.

I had too many bad bosses in my career.

They were masters in:

↳ Demotivating people
↳ Communicating with no clarity
↳ Making decisions based on their ego

It felt like every day was a never-ending episode of “What Not to Do as a Leader.”

Those experiences were rough for me.

I became frustrated and cynical about leadership.

Until I realized this was an opportunity to declare what type of leader I wanted to become.

In hindsight, here are a few key lessons I learned:

𝟏. 𝐂𝐥𝐚𝐫𝐢𝐭𝐲:
👉 Bad bosses are not good at clarifying their expectations and directions. 
Their ambiguity creates a strong sense of feeling lost and unproductive. 

𝟐.

Their ambiguity creates a strong sense of feeling lost and unproductive. 

𝟐. 𝐄𝐦𝐩𝐚𝐭𝐡𝐲:
👉 Their lack of empathy kills morale and prevents trust. 
Empathy is a superpower, creating an environment where people feel valued.

𝟑. 𝐋𝐞𝐚𝐫𝐧𝐢𝐧𝐠:
👉 Blame games and finger-pointing are bad bosses' favorite habits. 
Mistakes should be accepted and discussed openly as learning opportunities.

𝟒. 𝐌𝐢𝐧𝐝𝐬𝐞𝐭:
👉 Bad bosses are models of stagnation.

They resist change and cling to outdated practices. They are not interested in building a growth mindset.

𝟓. 𝐈𝐧𝐬𝐩𝐢𝐫𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧:
👉 Their leadership deficiencies sucked the motivation out of the room. Great bosses inspire and uplift their team, celebrating achievements, and encouraging them to reach their full potential.

In summary…

Look at your experience with a bad boss as a gift for: 

↳ Getting clarity about how to lead
↳ Learning good and bad leadership practices 
↳ Shape who you DON’T want to become as a leader

Leadership isn’t just about the title. It’s about the impact we have on others.

It’s about the impact we have on others.

Be a leader who focuses on impact 💪

What shaped your leadership development?

Average CEOs build average teams. 

Best CEOs build teams that last. 

Here are my insights from over 20 years of observing how CEOs build and develop their teams: 👇 

Average CEOs tend to:

↳ Pick people just like themselves
↳ Surround themselves with 'yes men' or friends
↳ Give positions as rewards, not based on contributions
↳ Create large teams that slow down decisions and actions

Great CEOs see things differently. They:

↳ Choose people who complement their skills
↳ Reward individuals based on their contributions
↳ Choose people who question the 'usual way' of doing things
↳  Form small & effective teams that are focused on performing

Here's the truth.

You are 5x more productive when you reach the flow state (which has nothing to do with talent or experience). Here's how:

In a 10-year study conducted by McKinsey & Company, top executives reported being 5x more productive in flow. 

Flow is a mental state when you feel you are "in the zone":

↳ Feeling extremely focused
↳ Fully immersed in an activity
↳ You enjoy the process of the task at hand

My 7 simple suggestions to be "in the flow":

1. Set clear goals: 
▶ Set clear, aspirational but achievable goals for you and/or your team to provide direction and a sense of accomplishment.

2.

2. Balance the challenge-skills force: 
▶ Ensure your challenge level is balanced with your skills level (or slightly higher) to keep high engagement with the tasks without causing burnout.

3. Optimize the work environment: 
▶ Adjust lighting, noise levels, and workplace layout to promote concentration and comfort, which are critical for achieving flow.

4. Minimize interruptions: 
▶ Create a work environment that reduces all distractions. Build working practices like 'focus hours' where you and your team members work undisturbed.

5. Give autonomy: 
▶ Allow team members the freedom to approach tasks in ways that best suit their unique strengths and skills.

6. Give immediate feedback: 
▶ Provide real-time, constructive feedback to help your people adjust and feel valued.

7.

6. Give immediate feedback: 
▶ Provide real-time, constructive feedback to help your people adjust and feel valued.

7. Encourage skills mastery: 
▶ Be an avid learner. Provide opportunities for your team to acquire new skills and knowledge that not only match their job requirements but also keep them challenged and engaged.

Final observation... 👇 

Peak performers are not more talented.

They just know how to be more productive in less time.

Double standards kill the company culture. Here are 7 powerful actions to prevent that: ⤵

1. Be clear in what you expect:
↳ Communicate clear behavioral standards that apply equally to everyone in the organization, regardless of their position or status.

2. Be the first:
↳ Model the behaviors you expect to see in others. As a leader, your actions set a tone for the entire team, so ensure you act with integrity.

3. Don't accept the unacceptable:
↳ Ensure that the consequences for not adhering to standards are the same for everyone. This reinforces the message that all employees are held to the same standards.

4. Walk around your offices:
↳ Don't spend too much time behind closed doors, losing touch with what's happening in their organizations.

Walk around your offices:
↳ Don't spend too much time behind closed doors, losing touch with what's happening in their organizations. You may unconsciously tolerate double standards.

5. Promote real conversations:
↳ Encourage team members to speak up about inconsistencies without fear of repercussions. Pretending that toxic behaviors don't exist is not a sign of leadership.

6. Create a feedback-driven organization:
↳ Give regular and constructive feedback to everyone. This not only promotes personal and professional growth but also demonstrates that all team members are valued equally.

7. Recognize and reward fairly:
↳ Make sure that recognition and rewards are based on merit and consistent across the board. Avoid favoritism that always creates the perception of double standards.

Avoid favoritism that always creates the perception of double standards.

In summary: 👇 

A double standard is when you expect most people to meet a certain standard, but you give some other people a pass.

This is the most effective way to lose your best people.

Agree? What action resonates the most with you?

7 key habits to make your words stick in someone’s mind: 🗣

2. Listen well:

↳ Don't just wait for your turn to talk. Listen to what others are saying. When people feel heard, they think more fondly of the conversation.

3. Share inspiring stories:

↳ Tell stories that are exciting or funny. Stories help your words stick in someone's mind long after the chat ends.

4. Ask genuine questions:

↳ Show you're interested by asking questions about what others say. This makes them feel important and they'll remember how caring you were.

This makes them feel important and they'll remember how caring you were.

6. Smile and be positive:

↳ When you smile and look happy, it makes your words feel warmer. People like talking to someone cheerful.

7. Say their name:

↳ People love hearing their names. Use it in the conversation, and they’ll feel more connected to what you’re saying.

How to make an impactful presentation (without spending weeks on dull PowerPoint slides): 👇

1. Passion always wins:
❇ Energize your audience with your enthusiasm—use simple, clear language to draw them into your passion.

2. Be short and catchy:
❇ Summarize your product in a crisp, catchy sentence that could fit in a tweet, making the core message instantly clear.

3. Power of three:
❇ Embrace the 'rule of three' for its simplicity and impact—grouping information in threes can be more memorable and engaging.

4. Stories make the audience stick:
❇ Introduce the 'villain'—the problem your solution solves—to highlight the 'hero', which is the solution you offer.

5.

5. People love heroes:
❇ Once the problem is established, showcase your solution as the 'hero' with compelling reasons why it's the solution.

6. Simple visual:
❇ Use slides that are visually appealing and easy to digest; minimize text to keep your audience focused on your message.

7. Lead with a personal touch:
❇ Share anecdotes about the solution's creation or role in your life, making your presentation more relatable and memorable.

8. Rehearse, rehearse, rehearse:
❇ Familiarize yourself with your material to boost your confidence and the smooth delivery of your presentation. Even if it's just a meeting.

9.

Even if it's just a meeting.

9. Engage, engage, engage:
❇ Avoid reading from notes as much as possible to demonstrate your deep engagement with the solution and confidence in your knowledge.

In summary...

Every conversation, meeting, and presentation is a unique opportunity to enroll people in what you offer.

But without:

↳ Preparation
↳ Attention to details
↳ Understanding of human psychology

It's just a waste of time.

How do you ensure your presentations leave a lasting impression? What resonates most with your style?

9 toxic behaviors we need to stop normalizing (and how to do that):

1. 24/7 Work: 

↳ Expecting employees to be always on is not only disrespectful. It will lead your people to disengage and burn out. 

💡: Create and enforce clear work boundaries. Encourage employees to turn off work notifications after hours and respect their time off.

2. Micromanagement: 

↳ Constant oversight makes employees feel undervalued and stifles creativity. Trust is key to empowerment and growth.

💡 : Focus on setting clear expectations and outcomes, then allow employees the freedom to meet these goals in their own way.

3.

💡 : Focus on setting clear expectations and outcomes, then allow employees the freedom to meet these goals in their own way.

3. Working Overtime: 

↳ Regularly expecting employees to work extra hours creates a culture where overwork is the norm and recognition is tied to time spent, not output.

💡 : Acknowledge and reward efficiency and productivity, not just extra hours. Encourage employees to work smarter, not longer.

4. Responding: 

↳ Expecting immediate responses to communication disrupts focus and builds up stress.

💡 : Establish reasonable response time expectations and use priority tags for urgent matters to reduce pressure.

5. Breaks: 

↳ Working without breaks decreases overall performance and can harm mental health.

💡 : Promote regular breaks to recharge.

Breaks: 

↳ Working without breaks decreases overall performance and can harm mental health.

💡 : Promote regular breaks to recharge. Consider break reminders or structured downtime to ensure employees rest.

6. Gender Stereotypes: 

↳ Assigning roles, tasks, or behaviors based on gender is discriminatory and limits the use of your people's talent.

💡 : Develop bias training and encourage diverse teams where roles are based on skills and interests, not gender.

7. Benefits: 

↳ Replacing meaningful benefits and support with less substantial perks makes employees feel undervalued.

💡 : Offer benefits that genuinely improve employees' quality of life, like health insurance or flexible working arrangements, reflecting that you value their well-being.

8.

8. Results: 

↳ Valuing only end results may lead to unethical behavior or cutting corners.

💡 : Create a culture that values the process as well as the outcome. Recognize efforts and ethical approaches to achieving goals.

9. Busyness: 

↳ Equating constant activity with importance brings inefficiency and poor performance.

💡 : Measure productivity in outcomes, not activity. Encourage strategic thinking and prioritize tasks to focus on what truly adds value.

What is the most toxic behavior among these? What else is missing? 👇

17 habits that separate confident from insecure people (+ my insights to help you navigate social interactions): 👇 

1. Mindset:
↳ Confident people are open to new ideas and different opinions. Insecure people are not very open and often think they know everything.

2. Validation:
↳ Confident people say nice things to others. Insecure people often look for others to make them feel good about themselves.

3. Learning:
↳ Confident people love to learn from others. Insecure people act as if they already know everything.

4. Responsibility:
↳ Confident people accept when they make a mistake and try to fix it. Insecure people often make excuses for their mistakes.

5. Principles:
↳ Confident people have strong beliefs and stick to them.

5. Principles:
↳ Confident people have strong beliefs and stick to them. Insecure people just do whatever makes them happy at the moment.

6. Mistakes:
↳ Confident people are okay with being wrong sometimes. Insecure people blame someone else when things go wrong.

7. Flaws:
↳ Confident people are okay with not being perfect. Insecure people try to cover up any weaknesses they have.

8. Thinking:
↳ Confident people usually think about the good things. Insecure people often think about bad things or what could go wrong.

9. Risks:
↳ Confident people are willing to take chances. Insecure people like to stay where they feel safe.

10.

Risks:
↳ Confident people are willing to take chances. Insecure people like to stay where they feel safe.

10. Gossip:
↳ Confident people don't say mean things about others. Insecure people often talk about others behind their backs.

11. Scarcity:
↳ Confident people think there's plenty for everyone. Insecure people worry there won't be enough and feel they have to take from others.

12. Giving:
↳ Confident people like to give and help others. Insecure people often think about what they can get from others.

13. Social:
↳ Confident people enjoy being with others. Insecure people might not like being around people as much.

Social:

14. Judgments:
↳ Confident people are okay with others being different. Insecure people often judge or criticize differences.

15. Laugh:
↳ Confident people can make fun of themselves and not feel bad. Insecure people are often worried about being embarrassed or what others think of them.

16. Decisions:
↳ Confident people can decide easily. Insecure people might find it hard to make up their minds.

17. Growth:
↳ Confident people keep trying to learn and get better. Insecure people often stick with what they know, even if it's not the best.

If you're ambitious, you're going to hate this post.

Patience is the necessary evil to become extraordinary.

But it's also a killing venom for those who can't wait to get results.

I know because I was one of them.

For a decade of my life, I couldn't accept being patient.

Any result was not enough for me. 

I always needed something more.

For a decade of my life, I couldn't accept being patient.

Any result was not enough for me. 

I always needed something more.

Here's my observation: 👇 

Ambitious individuals can become trapped by their urgency: 

↳  They work no-stop until their ambitions are met
↳ They sacrifice most of their time (and family)
↳ They always feel something is missing
↳  They don’t accept the status quo
↳  They hate and fight complacency

It's all amazing until you realize that the quicker you try to change, the less you gain from it.

If you decide to play the extraordinary game, expect:

↳ Slow progress
↳ Doubts and fears
↳ A lot of time spent learning
↳ Longer journey than you thought
↳ One step forward and two backward

Patience is the calm acceptance that things can happen in a different order than you have in mind. 

– David G. Allen

What's your relationship with ambition?
